original_title: Brooklyn: Emmons Avenue - Sheepshead Bay Road
text:
Emmons Ave., south side, opposite Sheepshead Bay Road. This eating establishment known as "Domenick's Hotel" in 1924 and as Huisma's Hotel in 1890 was demolished in 1934.

January 1924.

Eugene L. Armbruster Collection.

original_title: Brooklyn: Emmons Avenue - Sheepshead Bay Road
text:
Emmons Avenue, east from Sheepshead Bay Road, showing the piers, fishing boats and restaurants lining the Sheepshead Bay waterfront. On the extreme right is Shore Boulevard, at Manhattan Beach. Views 2, 3, and 4 show the new bulkhead, marked off by the line of spiles. All the old frame structure and piers on the water's edge will be razed and the avenue widened another twenty feet by the W. P. A. View 4 is in a westerly direction and shows, in the background, the Bayview Apartments.

View 1: April 5, 1934
View 2,3,4: June 27, 1934

Works Progress Administration
Five Boroughs Project

original_title: Brooklyn: Emmons Avenue - Sheepshead Bay Road
text:
Emmons Ave., south side, looking east from Sheepshead Bay Road. These shacks once the pride of Sheepshead Bay, were condemned by the City of New York, to make way for the new Emmons Ave., and Promenade.

July 8, 1933.

P. L. Sperr.

(1)

Sheepshead Bay (Brooklyn):  Viewing west on the Bay
from near Batchelder Street.

July 13, 1933

P. L. Sperr

(2)

Another view, from about Sheepshead Bay Road.  On the right is Emmons Avenue, and on the left Shore Boulevard, both being widened by W. P. A.

September 24, 1936

Works Progress Administration
Five Boroughs Project

View 3: July 1, 1941

P. L. Sperr

title: Sheepshead Bay - Brooklyn - [Lundy Brothers Restaurant - Bayview Apartments.]

text:
(1)
Sheepshead Bay, above the pedestrian bridge that connects the Sheepshead Bay area to the Manhattan Beach section. This view northward, from the Manhattan Beach side of the Bridge, shows Emmons Ave., between Sheepshead Bay Road (left and East 19th Street (right). The apartment house shown on the left is the only structure of its kind on the Ave. and is at the N.W. corner of Sheepshead Bay Road. The shacks abutting on the waters edge were razed in 1934. July 13, 1933.

P. L. Sperr.

(2)
The same, showing a more extensive view of the fore and backgrounds. Also seen at the left is Shore Boulevard. July 8, 1933.

P. L. Sperr.
title: Sheepshead Bay - Brooklyn - [Manhattan Beach.]

text:
(1)

title: Sheepshead Bay - Brooklyn - [Manhattan Beach.]

original_title: Brooklyn: Emmons Avenue - Sheepshead Bay Road
text:
Emmons Avenue, east from Sheepshead Bay Road, showing the W. P. A. widening the avenue, as part of the City's new belt parkway system which will gird the five boroughs. The thoroughfare was widened about twenty feet, which necessitated the filling in of part of Sheepshead Bay, the razing of old piers and boat houses, and the construction of a new bulkhead. The building--in Spanish architecture--seen on the left in the four views, is the Lundy Brothers Restaurant.

View 1: September 12, 1935
Views 2,3: September 26, 1935
View 4: November 18, 1936

Works Progress Administration
Five Boroughs Project

original_title: Brooklyn: Emmons Avenue - Sheepshead Bay Road
text:
(1)
Emmons Ave., north side, between Sheepshead Bay Road and East 19th Street. In the right background, is the New Lundy Restaurant, erected in 1934.
August 1, 1935.
P. L. Sperr.

(2)
The same, showing only 1825-1827, at the N.W. corner of East 19th Street.
July 9, 1936.
P. L. Sperr.

(3)
Showing Nos. 1807-1819 at the N.E. corner of Sheepshead Bay Road. The building with the conical roof once housed the only carousel, and was the first "movie", in the Sheepshead Bay area.
July 9, 1936.
P. L. Sperr.

Emmons Avenue, east from Sheepshead Bay Road to Ocean Avenue, showing operations, by the W. P. A., on the widening of the avenue. Also shown is the Bayview Apartments and Lundy's new restaurant, the latter visible on the extreme right of view 3.

View 1: September 24, 1935
View 2,3: September 26, 1935

Works Progress Administration
Five Boroughs Project

original_title: Brooklyn: Emmons Avenue - Sheepshead Bay Road
text:
Emmons Avenue, west from near Sheepshead Bay Road, showing W. P. A. men widening the thoroughfare, this being part of the city's new belt parkway system which girds New York's five boroughs. View 2 is from hear E. 15th Street and shows the B. M. T. Brighton Beach Subway in the background.

October 27, 1936
Views 1,2

Works Progress Administration
Five Boroughs Project

original_title: Brooklyn: Emmons Avenue - Sheepshead Bay Road
text:
Emmons Avenue, west from near Sheepshead Bay Road, showing the thoroughfare being widened and a new bulkhead erected by the W. P. A. Many old piers and boat-houses were razed and part of Sheepshead Bay filled in when the avenue was widened, as part of the city's belt highway system.

View 1: February 28, 1936
View 2: June 17, 1936

Works Progress Administration
Five Boroughs Project

original_title: Brooklyn: Emmons Avenue - Sheepshead Bay Road
text:

View 1: February 28, 1936
View 2: June 17, 1936

Works Progress Administration
Five Boroughs Project
